instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the related study on identifying the most important wavelengths for discriminating between healthy and diseased peanut plants infected with Athelia rolfsii?
Output: In the related study, in-situ spectroscopy was used to collect spectral reflectance of peanut leaves on lateral stems of plants infected with Athelia rolfsii.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to select the top ranked wavelengths in the related study on identifying the most important wavelengths for discriminating between healthy and diseased peanut plants infected with Athelia rolfsii?
Output: Feature extraction and band selection methods were used to select the top-ranked wavelengths in the related study on identifying the most important wavelengths for discriminating between healthy and diseased peanut plants infected with Athelia rolfsii.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the classification performance of the selected wavelengths in the related study on identifying the most important wavelengths for discriminating between healthy and diseased peanut plants infected with Athelia rolfsii and how far can this metric go?
Output: Classification accuracy was chosen as the metric to evaluate the performance of the selected wavelengths in the related study. The classification accuracy ranged from low to medium for diseased peanut plants from the 'Presymptomatic' and 'Mild' classes.

instruction: What machine learning models were used in the related study to identify the most important wavelengths for discriminating between healthy and diseased peanut plants infected with Athelia rolfsii?
Output: Different machine learning methods were used in the study to classify healthy peanut plants and plants infected with Athelia rolfsii at different disease stages.

instruction: Can the identified wavelengths using in-situ spectroscopy and machine learning be used in the related research to develop optical sensors for automated stem rot detection in peanut fields?
Output: Yes, the identified wavelengths using in-situ spectroscopy and machine learning can be used in the related research to develop optical sensors for automated stem rot detection in peanut fields. The study found that wavelengths of 501-505, 690-694, 763, and 884 nm were repeatedly selected by two or more feature selection methods as the most important wavelengths for discriminating between healthy and diseased peanut plants infected with Athelia rolfsii. These selected wavelengths can be applied in designing optical sensors that can detect stem rot in peanut fields automatically.
